segment.source: Exercise 4 - Identify Problems with USB Devices
segment.target: Exercise 4 - Identify Problems with USB Devices

segment.source: The USB host controllers can power down only after all of the devices connected to them have entered a low power state.
segment.target: The USB host controllers can power down only after all of the devices connected to them have entered a low power state.

segment.source: Exercise 4 - Identify Problems with USB Devices
segment.target: Exercise 4 - Identify Problems with USB Devices

segment.source: The USB host controllers can power down only after all of the devices connected to them have entered a low power state.
segment.target: The USB host controllers can power down only after all of the devices connected to them have entered a low power state.

segment.source: This means that USB devices must support selective suspend on Modern Standby devices to ensure that the SoC can enter DRIPS while the screen is off.
segment.target: This means that USB devices must support selective suspend on Modern Standby devices to ensure that the SoC can enter DRIPS while the screen is off.

segment.source: Part 1: Use a SleepStudy report to identify problems
segment.target: Part 1: Use a SleepStudy report to identify problems

segment.source: Download the pre-generated sleepstudy-report2.html report here.
segment.target: Download the pre-generated sleepstudy-report2.html report here.

segment.source: Open sleepstudy-report2.html with your favorite browser.
segment.target: Open sleepstudy-report2.html with your favorite browser.

segment.source: Notice that the system is able to consume as little as 120 mW during Standby (e.g. see Standby Session 6).
segment.target: Notice that the system is able to consume as little as 120 mW during Standby (e.g. see Standby Session 6).

segment.source: Click on Session 10.
segment.target: Click on Session 10.

segment.source: The system consumes 2.83 Watts of energy during 11 minutes and the DRIPS % is 0.
segment.target: The system consumes 2.83 Watts of energy during 11 minutes and the DRIPS % is 0.

segment.source: Look at the Top Offenders table.
segment.target: Look at the Top Offenders table.

segment.source: The USB host controller (SB.PCI0.XHC) is active for 99% of the session duration.
segment.target: The USB host controller (SB.PCI0.XHC) is active for 99% of the session duration.

segment.source: XHC is the USB 3.0 host controller.
segment.target: XHC is the USB 3.0 host controller.

segment.source: When the USB bus controller is active for minutes at a time in Modern Standby, it usually means that one USB device attached to the bus is not entering selective suspend, possibly because it doesn’t support selective suspend.
segment.target: When the USB bus controller is active for minutes at a time in Modern Standby, it usually means that one USB device attached to the bus is not entering selective suspend, possibly because it doesn’t support selective suspend.

segment.source: The next logical step is to determine which USB device is staying in D0 by looking at an ETL trace.
segment.target: The next logical step is to determine which USB device is staying in D0 by looking at an ETL trace.

segment.source: For more information on selective suspend, see the USB Selective Suspend topic on MSDN.
segment.target: For more information on selective suspend, see the USB Selective Suspend topic on MSDN.

segment.source: Part 2: Use an ETL trace to identify problems
segment.target: Part 2: Use an ETL trace to identify problems

segment.source: In order to further the USB investigation, an ETL trace was captured on the same system where the SleepStudy was generated.
segment.target: In order to further the USB investigation, an ETL trace was captured on the same system where the SleepStudy was generated.

segment.source: To investigate USB issues, you’ll use the DState graph and table.
segment.target: To investigate USB issues, you’ll use the DState graph and table.

segment.source: Download the pre-generated USBProblem.etl trace here.
segment.target: Download the pre-generated USBProblem.etl trace here.

segment.source: Open USBProblem.etl with WPA.
segment.target: Open USBProblem.etl with WPA.

segment.source: Drag and drop the DRIPS graph in the analysis tab.
segment.target: Drag and drop the DRIPS graph in the analysis tab.

segment.source: Look at the Non-Drips Reasons, and find the USB xHCI Host controller as a device preventing the system from entering DRIPS.
segment.target: Look at the Non-Drips Reasons, and find the USB xHCI Host controller as a device preventing the system from entering DRIPS.

segment.source: You can see that the device is active for 98% of the trace (as shown in the % Reason time column).
segment.target: You can see that the device is active for 98% of the trace (as shown in the % Reason time column).

segment.source: Zoom in the region where the USB xHCI Host controller is active.
segment.target: Zoom in the region where the USB xHCI Host controller is active.

segment.source: Select the device in the table.
segment.target: Select the device in the table.

segment.source: Right-click on the light blue interval in the graph, and select zoom.
segment.target: Right-click on the light blue interval in the graph, and select zoom.

segment.source: The % Reason time should now be 100%.
segment.target: The % Reason time should now be 100%.

segment.source: Find the Device Dstate graph under the Power category of the Graph Explorer.
segment.target: Find the Device Dstate graph under the Power category of the Graph Explorer.

segment.source: Drag and drop the Device Dstate graph in the analysis tab.
segment.target: Drag and drop the Device Dstate graph in the analysis tab.

segment.source: The Device DState graph shows the effective D-States of devices over time.
segment.target: The Device DState graph shows the effective D-States of devices over time.

segment.source: You can use the data to determine if a specific device enters the appropriate D-state while the system is in Modern Standby.
segment.target: You can use the data to determine if a specific device enters the appropriate D-state while the system is in Modern Standby.

segment.source: PoFx type: Used for devices managed by the Windows Power Management Framework.
segment.target: PoFx type: Used for devices managed by the Windows Power Management Framework.

segment.source: Non-PoFx type: Used for USB-attached devices.
segment.target: Non-PoFx type: Used for USB-attached devices.

segment.source: Move the DState column right next to the Type column.
segment.target: Move the DState column right next to the Type column.

segment.source: Your viewport should look like this:
segment.target: Your viewport should look like this:

segment.source: Expand the Non-PoFX category.
segment.target: Expand the Non-PoFX category.

segment.source: Expand the Dstate row with the 0x0 value (D0 state, or active).
segment.target: Expand the Dstate row with the 0x0 value (D0 state, or active).

segment.source: Sort by the Name column and find the USB devices.
segment.target: Sort by the Name column and find the USB devices.

segment.source: The data in the D-state table shows that, while the system was in standby, a USB composite device was still in state D0 for 100% of the time.
segment.target: The data in the D-state table shows that, while the system was in standby, a USB composite device was still in state D0 for 100% of the time.

segment.source: The hardware id of the composite device is USBVID0BB4&PID0BA100000015B42EE80F0000000000000000.
segment.target: The hardware id of the composite device is USBVID0BB4&PID0BA100000015B42EE80F0000000000000000.

segment.source: This is the device that was preventing the XHCI controller from powering down.
segment.target: This is the device that was preventing the XHCI controller from powering down.

segment.source: If the device is managed by a driver authored by Microsoft, please report the issue to Microsoft.
segment.target: If the device is managed by a driver authored by Microsoft, please report the issue to Microsoft.

segment.source: If not, then this information must be reported to the hardware vendor who owns the driver to find a solution and ensure that the device enters selective suspend.
segment.target: If not, then this information must be reported to the hardware vendor who owns the driver to find a solution and ensure that the device enters selective suspend.
